intro: Pyrus anglica, commonly known as the English pear or wild pear, is a deciduous tree native to Europe and western Asia. It typically grows to a height of 5–10 meters, featuring a rounded crown and smooth, gray bark. The leaves are alternate, ovate, and have a serrated margin, turning yellow in autumn. Its flowers are white and appear in clusters, followed by edible, yellow or orange fruits that ripen in late summer. The plant is often found in woodlands and along riverbanks, thriving in moist, well-drained soils.
